name: ferrochromium production, high-carbon, 68% Cr | ferrochromium, high-carbon, 68% Cr | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/24577/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg high-carbon ferrochromium (HC FeCr), which is used in the production of stainless steel and high chromium steel. The original data are taken from the European Commission JRC report on the Best Available Techniques (BAT) for the Non-Ferrous Metals Industries (Cusano et al. 2017). This dataset is a copy of the geography Kazakhstan. ;Reference:;Gianluca Cusano, Miguel Rodrigo Gonzalo, Frank Farrell, Rainer Remus, Serge Roudier, Luis Delgado Sancho (2017). Best Available Techniques (BAT) Reference Document for the main Non-Ferrous Metals Industries, EUR 28648, doi:10.2760/8224;[This dataset is meant to replace the following datasets:]

The activity starts with chromite and other materials entering the factory gate.

The activity ends with the carbothermal reduction of chromite and the production of high-carbon ferrochromium. Emissions to water and air are included, as well as infrastructure and waste.
category: C:Manufacturing/24:Manufacture of basic metals/241:Manufacture of basic iron and steel/2410:Manufacture of basic iron and steel

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The time period is from 2017 (publication of data) to 2021 (creation of the datasets)
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This dataset represents the global geography. It is a copy of the geography Kazakhstan. The production volume and the uncertainty are updated accordingly.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: High-carbon ferrochromium (HC FeCr) is produced at high temperatures via the carbothermal reduction of chromite, smelted in electric arc furnaces. Inputs to the arc furnace are oxide of iron and chromium (chromite, with Cr/Fe = 3.8 in Kazakhstan), coke or coal (used as reducing agent), dolomite, silica and/or bauxite (used as fluxing agents for slag formation). The smelting charge can be pre-heated and pre-reduced in a rotary kiln.Water is used during the operations. Main emissions from the smelting process are dust and fume. Dust occur from storage, handling and pre-treatment of raw materials. Depending on the raw material and on the process, other emissions to air are SO2, NOx, CO-gas, CO2, polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH), VOCs, and volatile metals. The formation of dioxins is possible. Process residues and by-products are mainly slag and filter dust (or dry cake, considered as inert material).;;Reference:;USGS 2016. Minerals Yearbook - Ferroalloys. Available at: https://prd-wret.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/assets/palladium/production/atoms/files/myb1-2016-feall.pdf  ;Gianluca Cusano, Miguel Rodrigo Gonzalo, Frank Farrell, Rainer Remus, Serge Roudier, Luis Delgado Sancho (2017). Best Available Techniques (BAT) Reference Document for the main Non-Ferrous Metals Industries, EUR 28648, doi:10.2760/8224
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: The data are extrapolated from the original dataset for KZ.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
Literature and estimation from Cusano et al. (2017) and Classen et al. (2009). See comments to exchanges for details. 

References:
Cusano, G., Gonzalo, M.R., Farrell, F., Remus, R., Roudier, S., Delgado Sancho, L. (2017). Best Available Techniques (BAT) Reference Document for the main Non-Ferrous Metals Industries, EUR 28648, doi:10.2760/8224
Classen, M., Althaus, H.-J., Blaser, S., Tuchschmid, M., Jungbluth, N., Doka, G., Faist Emmenegger, M., Scharnhorst, W. (2009). Life Cycle Inventories of Metals. Final report ecoinvent data v2.1, No 10. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH, Online-Version under: www.ecoinvent.ch

flow.name: ferrochromium, high-carbon, 68% Cr
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/24:Manufacture of basic metals/241:Manufacture of basic iron and steel/2410:Manufacture of basic iron and steel

exchanges.description: Literature. The original values are reported in Table 8.18 in Cusano et al. (2017). Chromium(IV) is emitted to air from a semi-closed furnace. Chromium(IV) emission is 0.1-0.3% of total dust emissions, which account for 20-80 kg/t ferrochromium (Table 8.26 in Cusano et al., 2017).

flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
Literature. Original values are reported in Table 8.5 in Cusano et al. (2017). The value is calculated as average between conventional open submerged furnace and more modern furnaces with pre-heating or pre-reduction processes. 
EcoSpold01Location=UCTE

exchanges.description: Calculated value, based on stoichiometry and carbon content of coke and the reference product. Carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide originate from the reaction of C contained in coke (reducing agent) with oxygen available in the air. C MW=12.01 g/mol; O MW= 15.99 g/mol. The split between CO and CO2 (0.0017 and 0.9983) is based on the carbon content of CO and CO2 respectively in the dataset "heat production, at coal coke industrial furnace 10 MW".

exchanges.description: Literature. Original values are reported in Table 8.5 in Cusano et al. (2017). Coke is the main reducing agent in the carbothermal reduction of chromite. The value is calculated as average between conventional open submerged furnace and more modern furnaces with pre-heating or pre-reduction processes. The gross calorific value of coke from hard coal (metallurgical coke) is 28.9 MJ/kg, taken from Weidema et al. 2013 ("Overview and methodology - data quality guideline for the ecoinvent database version 3")

exchanges.description: Calculated value. According to Cusano et al. (2017), emissions total dust is 20-80 kg/t ferrochrome, of which a defined share is given by the emissions of Cr, Cr(VI) and cyanides (Table 8.26). The size differentiation of PM is based on the proportion reported in Kuenen 2019 (EMEP/EEA air pollutant emission inventory guidebook 2019 - 2.C.2 Ferro-alloys production), Table 3.1: 60% PM<2.5um; 85%-60%=25% PM >2.5 & <10um; 100%-85%=15% PM>10um

exchanges.description:
Literature. Original values are reported in Table 8.5 in Cusano et al. (2017). Since the share of different fluxing agents (e.g. dolomite, bauxite, silica sand, lime) is unknown, bauxite is assumed to be the unique fluxing agent. The value is calculated as average between conventional open submerged furnace and more modern furnaces with pre-heating or pre-reduction processes. 
EcoSpold01Location=GLO

exchanges.description:
Literature. According to Cusano et al. (2017), filter cake containes 20-25% moisture, and the amount of dry cake generated from wastewater is 200-400 kg/t of alloy. Filter cake is processed further to extract zinc and lead, rather than being sent to landfill.
EcoSpold01Location=CH

exchanges.description: Calculated value, based on stoichiometry and carbon content of coke and the reference product. Carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide originate from the reaction of C contained in coke (reducing agent) with oxygen available in the air. C MW=12.01 g/mol; O MW= 15.99 g/mol. The split between CO and CO2 (0.0017 and 0.9983) is based on the carbon content of CO and CO2 respectively in the dataset "heat production, at coal coke industrial furnace 10 MW".

exchanges.description:
Literature. According to Cusano et al. (2017), filter cake containes 20-25% moisture, and the amount of dry cake generated from wastewater is 200-400 kg/t of alloy. Filter cake is processed further to extract zinc and lead, rather than being sent to landfill.
EcoSpold01Location=CH

exchanges.description: Calculated value. According to Cusano et al. (2017), emissions total dust is 20-80 kg/t ferrochrome, of which a defined share is given by the emissions of Cr, Cr(VI) and cyanides (Table 8.26). The size differentiation of PM is based on the proportion reported in Kuenen 2019 (EMEP/EEA air pollutant emission inventory guidebook 2019 - 2.C.2 Ferro-alloys production), Table 3.1: 60% PM<2.5um; 85%-60%=25% PM >2.5 & <10um; 100%-85%=15% PM>10um

flow.name: Particulate Matter, > 2.5 um and < 10um
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description: Literature. The original values are reported in Table 8.18 in Cusano et al. (2017). Cyanides are emitted to air from a closed furnace. The emissions are 0.02-0.05 kg per metric ton of HC-FeCr produced.
